text:
OK, I can do 1 and 2.

I tested on a horse market with 11 runners and it's taking 7 seconds to create the data and then 45 seconds to make the plots.

If I remove my new code it takes 4 seconds to create the data and 4 seconds to make the plots.

Which I think makes sense as the book percentage plots have two curves, so that's 2 seconds per curve.  For the prices plot there's 2 curves per runner so 11 (runners) * 2 (curves) * 2 (seconds/curve) = 44 seconds.

text: Thinking of moving my live model code into the flumine framework. I quite like that it seems to have the option to simulate execution and run backtest/live interchangeably. I want to 1) get the current score, and 2) do some calculations on all matches within an event to generate a return forecast. From the `tennsiexample.py` I gather that the correct way to do this within flumine is to add a background worker that generates a custom event once it is done doing all its calcs. Then move the return forecast into market context when processing custom event. Or is there a more straight forward way to do this within flumine?

elements.text: Thinking of moving my live model code into the flumine framework. I quite like that it seems to have the option to simulate execution and run backtest/live interchangeably. I want to 1) get the current score, and 2) do some calculations on all matches within an event to generate a return forecast. From the
tennsiexample.py

I gather that the correct way to do this within flumine is to add a background worker that generates a custom event once it is done doing all its calcs. Then move the return forecast into market context when processing custom event. Or is there a more straight forward way to do this within flumine?

text: Depends how slow the calculation is, you can use a worker to update the context and do it in the strategy itself or like you describe in a worker

elements.text: Depends how slow the calculation is, you can use a worker to update the context and do it in the strategy itself or like you describe in a worker

text: By doing it in the strategy itself I assume you mean run the calc for each market? The calculation is not super slow, but slow enough that I’d rather run it only once for all markets.

elements.text: By doing it in the strategy itself I assume you mean run the calc for each market? The calculation is not super slow, but slow enough that I’d rather run it only once for all markets.

text: Or did you mean run the calculation in a market, post the result + timestamp to context and then only rerun in the next market being processed if last calc is more than x seconds/minutes ago?

elements.text: Or did you mean run the calculation in a market, post the result + timestamp to context and then only rerun in the next market being processed if last calc is more than x seconds/minutes ago?

text: If I understand this correctly, background workers are by default spun off as threads, so presumably there is not much speed advantage in doing so (maybe a little bit faster during the get request of the score data).

elements.text: If I understand this correctly, background workers are by default spun off as threads, so presumably there is not much speed advantage in doing so (maybe a little bit faster during the get request of the score data).

text: yeah if its shared do it in the worker and then make available to all markets that need it via context or similar

elements.text: yeah if its shared do it in the worker and then make available to all markets that need it via context or similar

text: Ok that’s what I figured

elements.text: Ok that’s what I figured

text: I presume I could spin off the calcs as a process and feed the results back to the main process as they come in.

elements.text: I presume I could spin off the calcs as a process and feed the results back to the main process as they come in.

text: If Betfair fails to suspend during material event for a managed market, what is the process to raise with them? Usually just wait and they will reconcile / void bets or best to shoot an email?

elements.text: If Betfair fails to suspend during material event for a managed market, what is the process to raise with them? Usually just wait and they will reconcile / void bets or best to shoot an email?

text: Ok…problem solved. All bets that I thought occurred over material event have been voided. That being said, if anyone can guide me to the flag to check managed / not managed markets would be very helpful.

elements.text: Ok…problem solved. All bets that I thought occurred over material event have been voided. That being said, if anyone can guide me to the flag to check managed / not managed markets would be very helpful.

text: I'm not sure there is a specific flag. There are specific unmanaged markets that have different market types

elements.text: I'm not sure there is a specific flag. There are specific unmanaged markets that have different market types

text: It's not always specified by the market type, sometimes it's identifiable by the market name, but that's not a guarantee either. As far as I can tell there's no definitive way to tell.

elements.text: It's not always specified by the market type, sometimes it's identifiable by the market name, but that's not a guarantee either. As far as I can tell there's no definitive way to tell.

text: I spoke to Neil about this recently because I had a big spike in getting arbed over these events (clearly something happened to timely suspensions). My only form of recourse was to raise it with customer support which then gets escalated. Tbh this process is very easy and also quite quick so bit of a silver lining.

elements.text: I spoke to Neil about this recently because I had a big spike in getting arbed over these events (clearly something happened to timely suspensions). My only form of recourse was to raise it with customer support which then gets escalated. Tbh this process is very easy and also quite quick so bit of a silver lining.

text: The only thing I would say is don't rely on things being automatically voided/re-settled, and actively query your fills which were clearly off-market.

elements.text: The only thing I would say is don't rely on things being automatically voided/re-settled, and actively query your fills which were clearly off-market.

text: What was Neil's response? As I'm currently avoiding trading in certain situations due to this issue.

elements.text: What was Neil's response? As I'm currently avoiding trading in certain situations due to this issue.

text: Consoling in the sense that it should be expected for: a) bets to be voided if markets remain open following a goal and you get matched after the official goal time and b) markets should be suspended when penalties are awarded/red cards given so bets will be voided if they were matched when there was a failure for suspension to take place. And the right thing to do is to raise this with customer service (or bdp actually) to have it escalated and disputed.

elements.text: Consoling in the sense that it should be expected for: a) bets to be voided if markets remain open following a goal and you get matched after the official goal time and b) markets should be suspended when penalties are awarded/red cards given so bets will be voided if they were matched when there was a failure for suspension to take place. And the right thing to do is to raise this with customer service (or bdp actually) to have it escalated and disputed.

text: I'm going to be lazy and ask to see if anyone has a quick answer, is there a way to fetch a corresponding market on the same event through the stream? e.g. Wanting to bet on over/under 1.5 goals but need the correct score market for some calculations

elements.text: I'm going to be lazy and ask to see if anyone has a quick answer, is there a way to fetch a corresponding market on the same event through the stream? e.g. Wanting to bet on over/under 1.5 goals but need the correct score market for some calculations

text:
if you are a flumine user and assuming the market is available in your filter:

```correct_score_market = market.event["CORRECT_SCORE"]```

elements.text: if you are a flumine user and assuming the market is available in your filter:
correct_score_market = market.event["CORRECT_SCORE"]
